_**Night at the Museum**_ is a 2006 American [fantasy](/wiki/Fantasy_film
"Fantasy film")-[comedy film](/wiki/Comedy_film "Comedy film") directed by
[Shawn Levy](/wiki/Shawn_Levy "Shawn Levy") and written by [Robert Ben
Garant](/wiki/Robert_Ben_Garant "Robert Ben Garant") and [Thomas
Lennon](/wiki/Thomas_Lennon "Thomas Lennon"), based on the 1993 [children's
book of the same name](/wiki/The_Night_at_the_Museum "The Night at the
Museum") by [Croatian](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia") illustrator [Milan
Trenc](/wiki/Milan_Trenc "Milan Trenc"). The film stars [Ben
Stiller](/wiki/Ben_Stiller "Ben Stiller") as Larry Daley, a
[divorced](/wiki/Divorce "Divorce") father who applies for a job as a [night
watchman](/wiki/Security_guard "Security guard") at New York City's [American
Museum of Natural History](/wiki/American_Museum_of_Natural_History "American
Museum of Natural History") and subsequently discovers that the exhibits,
animated by a magical [Egyptian](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt")
artifact, come to life at night.

It was released on December 22, 2006 by [20th Century
Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox"). The first installment in the
[_Night at the Museum_ trilogy](/wiki/Night_at_the_Museum_\(film_series\)
"Night at the Museum \(film series\)"), the film was a box office success
despite receiving mixed reviews from critics, grossing over $574 million.

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Larry Daley is a divorced man from [Queens](/wiki/Queens "Queens"), hoping to
find a good job to impress his ten-year old son Nick, his ex-wife Erica
believing he is a bad example for their son. Larry is hired at the [American
Museum of Natural History](/wiki/American_Museum_of_Natural_History "American
Museum of Natural History") to replace the retiring [security
guards](/wiki/Security_guard "Security guard") Cecil Fredericks and his
colleagues Gus and Reginald. Larry meets the museum’s neurotic curator Dr.
McPhee, and [museum docent](/wiki/Museum_docent "Museum docent") Rebecca
Hutman, who plans to write a [dissertation](/wiki/Dissertation "Dissertation")
on [Sacagawea](/wiki/Sacagawea "Sacagawea"). On his first night, Cecil hands
Larry an instruction manual on what to do in the museum, warning him not to
let anything “in or out.”

Larry soon discovers that at night, the museum’s exhibits come to life and
cause havoc for him. Amongst the lively exhibits are a playful
_[Tyrannosaurus](/wiki/Tyrannosaurus "Tyrannosaurus")_ skeleton named Rexy; a
mischievous [capuchin monkey](/wiki/Capuchin_monkey "Capuchin monkey") named
Dexter who destroys the instructions; the warring factions of
[cowboys](/wiki/Cowboy "Cowboy") and [legionnaires](/wiki/Roman_legion "Roman
legion") led by Jedediah and General Octavius; violent [Attila the
Hun](/wiki/Attila_the_Hun "Attila the Hun"); a talking [Easter Island
Head](/wiki/Easter_Island_Head "Easter Island Head") that desires gum; the
fire-seeking [neanderthals](/wiki/Neanderthal "Neanderthal"); and a wax model
of [Theodore Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore Roosevelt"), who is
in love with Sacagawea.

Roosevelt explains to Larry that the exhibits have come to life every night
since the arrival of an Egyptian artifact, the Tablet of Akhmenrah, the
mummified pharaoh trapped in his sarcophagus. He also explains to Larry that
as night guard, it is his job to make sure that no exhibit sets foot out of
the museum, otherwise they will disintegrate into dust if the sun rises while
they are outside. The next day, Cecil advises Larry to research history to
make up for the instructions’ destruction. He studies in libraries and from
Rebecca. Larry puts his new knowledge to good use on his second night, but
some of his plans backfire and the neanderthals set their exhibit on fire,
leading to one becoming dust after venturing outside. After having doubts and
almost getting fired the next day, Larry offers to introduce Sacagawea to
Rebecca, but she thinks he is mocking her.

On his third night, Larry brings Nick to the museum to watch the exhibits come
to life, but they strangely do not. They catch Cecil, Gus, and Reginald
stealing artifacts, who explain the tablet’s magic has allowed them to feel
physically young in their old age, and plot to frame Larry for the theft while
they enjoy a happy retirement. Nick activates the tablet, but Cecil steals it,
locking Larry and Nick in the Egyptian exhibit. They free Akhmenrah, and rally
the exhibits to stop the thieves and retrieve their colleagues who fled out
into [Central Park](/wiki/Central_Park "Central Park"). Gus and Reginald are
captured, but Cecil escapes by [stagecoach](/wiki/Stagecoach "Stagecoach").

Larry and several exhibits give chase, where they stop Cecil and recover the
tablet, using its magic to escort all of the exhibits back into the museum
before sunrise. Rebecca witnesses this and makes amends with Larry,
subsequently introduced to Sacagawea. The next day McPhee fires Larry, but
when they go into the museum, they find it is crowded due to last night’s
strange activities, and Larry is rehired. During the credits, Cecil, Gus, and
Reginald were granted mercy by Larry and work as janitors.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Production")]

The building featured in the film, which was constructed on a sound stage in
[Burnaby](/wiki/Burnaby "Burnaby"), [British Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia
"British Columbia"), is based on the [American Museum of Natural
History](/wiki/American_Museum_of_Natural_History "American Museum of Natural
History") in New York City, external shots of which were used in the movie.[2]

Trainers spent several weeks training Crystal, who plays the troublemaking
monkey Dexter, to slap and bite Stiller in the film.

Robin Williams' Theodore Roosevelt costume closely resembles that of [John
Wayne](/wiki/John_Wayne "John Wayne")'s character in _The Shootist_.[3]

Director [Shawn Levy](/wiki/Shawn_Levy "Shawn Levy") credited Ben Stiller for
the ensemble cast: "When actors hear that Ben Stiller is in a movie they want
to work with him. It['s] a high-water mark and it absolutely draws actors in
and I'm convinced that's a big part of why we got this cast."[4]

### Songs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Songs")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/63/Benstillertrex.jpg/250px-
Benstillertrex.jpg)](/wiki/File:Benstillertrex.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Benstillertrex.jpg "Enlarge")

Ben Stiller claimed that he watched [Tom Cruise](/wiki/Tom_Cruise "Tom
Cruise") in the _[Mission:
Impossible](/wiki/Mission:_Impossible_\(film_series\) "Mission: Impossible
\(film series\)")_ films to learn how to imitate his running technique, shown
here as Stiller portraying his film character running for dear life from the
_Tyrannosaurus rex_ skeleton (Rexy).[4]

  * "[Friday Night](/wiki/Sorry%27s_Not_Good_Enough/Friday_Night "Sorry's Not Good Enough/Friday Night")" \- performed by [McFly](/wiki/McFly_\(band\) "McFly \(band\)"); not featured in American version of the film, but heard in some international cuts, used during the end credits. It can be heard on the American DVD on the Spanish dub.
  * "[September](/wiki/September_\(Earth,_Wind_%26_Fire_song\) "September \(Earth, Wind & Fire song\)")" \- performed by [Earth, Wind and Fire](/wiki/Earth,_Wind_and_Fire "Earth, Wind and Fire"); used before the end credits where everyone in the museum is partying.
  * "[Weapon of Choice](/wiki/Star_69_/_Weapon_of_Choice "Star 69 / Weapon of Choice")" \- performed by [Fatboy Slim](/wiki/Fatboy_Slim "Fatboy Slim"); used in the scene where Larry returns to the museum for his second night and is preparing for the chaos.
  * "Tonight" \- performed by [Keke Palmer](/wiki/Keke_Palmer "Keke Palmer") and [Cham](/wiki/Cham_\(singer\) "Cham \(singer\)"); used for the end credits (U.S. theatrical version only).
  * "[Eye of the Tiger](/wiki/Eye_of_the_Tiger "Eye of the Tiger")" \- performed by Ben Stiller; used in the scene where Larry is bored and messes around with the telephone at the front desk beatboxing the music.
  * An [instrumental](/wiki/Elevator_music "Elevator music") version of "[Mandy](/wiki/Mandy_\(Barry_Manilow_song\) "Mandy \(Barry Manilow song\)")" by [Barry Manilow](/wiki/Barry_Manilow "Barry Manilow") is used when Larry is standing in the elevator, while escaping from Attila the Hun.
  * "[Ezekiel Saw Them Dry Bones](/wiki/Dem_Bones "Dem Bones")" is the tune Larry whistles as he passes the empty _T. rex_ exhibit on his first night.
  * "[Camptown Races](/wiki/Camptown_Races "Camptown Races")" by Stephen Foster is sung by the townspeople of the American West miniature diorama. This is a period-correct song.

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Release")]

_Night at the Museum_ had its [premiere](/wiki/Film_premiere "Film premiere")
in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") on December 17, 2006,
in South Korea on December 21, 2006, on December 22, 2006 in United States,
December 26, 2006 in UK, January 12, 2007 in Brazil, on February 14, 2007 in
China and on March 17, 2007 in Japan.[7]

The film was released under the title of "Noche en el museo" in Spain, "Una
notte al museo" in Italy, "La nuit au musée" in France, "Ночь в музее" in
Russia and "Uma Noite no Museu" in Brazil.[7]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Box office")]

At the end of its box office run, _Night at the Museum_ earned a gross of
$250.9 million in the US and Canada and $323.6 million in other territories,
for a worldwide total of $574.5 million against a budget of $110 million.[1]
It is also the highest-grossing film worldwide of the trilogy.[8]

It was the highest-grossing film in its opening weekend, grossing $30.8
million plating in 3,685 theaters, with a $8,258 per-theater average. For the
four-day Christmas holiday weekend, it took in $42.2 million.[1] The movie was
also released in [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") large screen format, often on site
at museums of science or natural history such as the [Pacific Science
Center](/wiki/Pacific_Science_Center "Pacific Science Center") in Seattle.

In its [second weekend](/wiki/Second_weekend_in_box_office_performance "Second
weekend in box office performance"), _Night at the Museum_ expanded into 83
more theaters and took in approximately $36.7 million, out-grossing its
opening weekend. It maintained the top position in its third week, with an
additional $23.7 million.[9]

During its opening weekend of December 15, 2006, the film grossed a figure of
estimated $5 million, with the highest debut coming from South Korea ($5.04
million).[10] The biggest market in the other territories were the UK, Japan,
South Korea, and Germany, where it grossed $40.8 million, $30 million, $25.7
million, $22.9 million.[11]

### Critical
reaction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Critical reaction")]

_Night at the Museum_ received mixed reviews from critics. On [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") the film has an approval
rating of 43%, based on 132 reviews, with an average rating of 5.3/10. The
site's critical consensus reads, "Parents might call this either a spectacle-
filled adventure or a shallow and vapid CG-fest, depending on whether they
choose to embrace this on the same level as their kids".[12] On
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), the film a score of 48 out of
100, based on 28 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".[13]

James Berardinelli of Reelviews gave it 2 stars out of 4, and commented on
Stiller's performance by stating "It might be fair to give Ben Stiller an 'A'
for effort, but to call what he does in this movie "acting" is a misnomer. He
does a lot of running around, occasionally falling down or bumping into
things."[14] One positive review by William Arnold of the _[Seattle Post-
Intelligencer](/wiki/Seattle_Post-Intelligencer "Seattle Post-Intelligencer")_
, gave it a B-, and stated that the film was "Out to impress and delight a
family audience with the pageantry of human and natural history, and that's a
surprisingly worthy ambition for a Hollywood comedy."[15] In a case of [life
imitating art](/wiki/Life_imitating_art "Life imitating art"), museum
officials at the [American Museum of Natural
History](/wiki/American_Museum_of_Natural_History "American Museum of Natural
History") have credited the film for increasing the number of visitors during
the holiday season by almost 20%. According to a museum official, between
December 22, 2006, and January 2, 2007, there were 50,000 more visitors than
during the same period the prior year.[16] [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore
"CinemaScore") polls conducted during the opening weekend, cinema audiences
gave the film an average grade of "A-" on an A+ to F scale.[17]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Home media")]

The film was released on a 2-Disc DVD edition in the United Kingdom on April
2, 2007. It was released on 1-Disc and 2-Disc [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") editions
and [Blu-ray Disc](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc") format on April 24, 2007
elsewhere.

The film became the first non-Disney film to be reviewed by Ultimate Disney
(now known as DVDizzy.com), due to the website dealing with other studios
besides [Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney
Company").[18][19]

As of 6 December
2009[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit),
the film has sold 9,191,694 DVDs and grossed $153,566,058 in DVD sales.[20]

##
Sequels[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Night_at_the_Museum&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Sequels")]

Main articles: [Night at the Museum: Battle of the
Smithsonian](/wiki/Night_at_the_Museum:_Battle_of_the_Smithsonian "Night at
the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian") and [Night at the Museum: Secret of
the Tomb](/wiki/Night_at_the_Museum:_Secret_of_the_Tomb "Night at the Museum:
Secret of the Tomb")

The first installment in the
[trilogy](/wiki/Night_at_the_Museum_\(film_series\) "Night at the Museum
\(film series\)"), _Night at the Museum_ was followed by a sequel titled
_Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian,[24]_ which was released on
May 22, 2009 in North America. The third and final installment, _Night at the
Museum: Secret of the Tomb_ , was released on December 19, 2014 in North
